title: Youtube on Firefox for Windows 10 always forces me to play at the highest available resolution
content: I'm using firefox 88.0.1, Windows 10. I also use "Adblock plus" and "YouTube enhancer". When I watch a YouTube video, it almost always forces the highest resolution. I don't mean "default", I mean "force". When I change the resolution to 480p (or anything else) it immediately reverts to the highest setting. Then it buffers (preloads) the video, using much more bandwidth than just the "per minute" toll for 1080p, because it is using bandwidth for the preloading as well. Is anyone else experiencing this (I think it started just this month, May 2021, or not long before that)?
creator: dem.nisbet

title: Downloading Mozilla Firefox using Windows Edge on Windows 10: digital certificate-unknown publisher & Mozilla Maintenance Serv auto install
content:
I downloaded Mozilla Firefox a few days ago using Windows Edge on Windows 10. The system notification at the time of installation asking me if I wanted the app to make changes on my PC did state the publisher was Mozilla Corporation. However when I went into MS App list in settings, I noticed Mozilla Maintenance Service had also been installed without asking me for my permission.

Even more concerning when I tried to uninstall Mozilla Maintenance Service a system notification asking me if I wanted the app to make changes to my PC stated the digital certificate for that app had an unknown publisher. I also checked the newly installed Mozilla Firefox browser app and the system notification again stated its digital certificate had an unknown publisher.

I left both apps installed and today I tried to view the certificates via the MS Management Console, the certificate store (accessed by pressing the windows key and R and typing certmgr.msc into the pop up search box). MMS could not find the certificates for either the Mozilla Firefox browser or Mozilla Maintenance Service apps. I've now managed to find copies of the digital certificates for both apps in my C drive under Program Files and Program Files (x86) but I am still concerned that the apps could be trojans. If anyone can answer some or all of the below questions I would be very grateful.

Has anyone had similar problems with Mozilla Firefox browser and Mozilla Maintenance Maintenance: 1) Not being able to find their digital certificate using the MS Management Console? 2) The apps list in settings stating publisher unknown when you try to uninstall either app? 3) Mozilla Maintenance Service automatically being installed when I only selected to download the Mozilla Firefox browser app? And lastly, is the C drive on the PC the correct place to view digital certificates for these apps?

title: Firefox keeps asking for a master password
content:
Firefox keeps asking for a master password: Translated with Bing Translator: The proposed measures https://support.mozilla.org/de/kb/firefox-fragt-immer-wieder-nach-master-passwort have been implemented, but to no avail. The request to enter the main password is often done 3 times in a row after the start of Firefox! This is extremely annoying! It would be good if you could turn off the prompt and activate it only if necessary (login to a website).

In German: Übersetzt mit Bing- Translator: Die vorgeschlagenen Maßnahmen https://support.mozilla.org/de/kb/firefox-fragt-immer-wieder-nach-master-passwort wurden durchgeführt, jedoch ohne Erfolg. Die Aufforderung, das Hauptpasswort einzugeben, erfolgt nach dem Start von Firefox oft 3 mal hintereinander! Das ist äußerst lästig! Es wäre gut, wenn man die Aufforderung abschalten könnte und nur bei Bedarf (Login bei einer Website) aktivieren könnte.

title: Feature request: sorting and grouping synced tabs by window
content:
I'm aware this has been asked before, and got the answer "at present, this problem can't be solved completely at the technical level" which ... well, isn't very informative, and is rather difficult to accept at face value.

Is there some fundamental issue stopping synced tab entries from having some attribute added to them that would help delineate this? To someone with no programming skills this doesn't sound like it would be hard, though of course I have no idea how the Firefox Sync system works. Still, I'm not asking for a function to restore entire sessions across systems, for example (I can see how that would cause conflicts with the current session) but rather just something that would a) sort tabs by window in the synced tabs list, and b) delineate the windows somehow, either by just a separator line or by some heading ("Window n"?). Given that this information clearly exists in the local session (it's able to restore all windows, after all), I hope it will be possible to add this in some form. To reiterate, I don't want/need it to automatically open synced tabs in the "correct" window or anything like that (I can handle that myself easily enough), but simply to keep them visually sorted and separated in the sync list. This way I can avoid spending 30 minutes sorting tabs that I had previously sorted in case of a system crash or working on a new PC.

In addition to this, I hope the sync system can move to match tab order in the browser rather than the current jumbled mess, which ... might be sorted by whatever was last active? I frankly can't tell, but for those of us with many tabs open at once and working across several devices this is a serious obstacle.

title: [Suggestion] Turning off as default the most of the Firefox Data Collection and Use
content:
I would like to suggest that the most options in the "Firefox Data Collection and Use" section in the settings are default turned off (except crash reports). This way the privacy and the speed of the browser increases by avoiding the collecting and sending the informations about the user (it may contain any sensitive informations, like: hardware and system informations, the runned applications and websites, etc.) to no one realy knows to who, with may be get "drop eared" and missused, with can create an security threat.

Additionally, holding the collected thru Firefox informations thru 30 days is in my opinion way too long

title: Specific Firefox process has very high CPU usage, causing my system to stay constantly spiked at 100% (and consequently get very hot)
content:
This is being categorized as privacy and security issues since every other search I've done for such issues point to plugins or datamining/cryptomining viruses. I've done every possible scan for my system for viruses and nothing popped up, I've browsed Explorer manually for all the files and any possible anomalies, and nothing strange has come up.

I've attached an image of the specific process that is doing this. I would like actual help, not just "check your plugins" or "run an AV scan" or something of that sort. If it's an obvious troubleshooting step, I've already tried it to no avail. Not trying to be rude, I just don't like "support experts" that give super obvious advice when it's clear the asker already has knowledge of it.

Some further clarifications:

  • Once ended through task manager, the process does not run again until I reboot my computer.
  • Forcing it to shut down through the task manager does not close my firefox if it's open, nor does it affect it in any functional way from my observations. This process is seemingly entirely useless, which only further raises suspicion.

title: need to recover bookmarks WITHOUT using Mozilla standard proceedures - had catastrophy
content:
My 11y/o Win7 Pro x64 based water cooled monster finally failed taking the Intel DX79si m/b, the PNY Nvidea GTX980 and 2 of the 8 - 8gb mem sticks with it. The 16TB and 8TB add-in raid cards survived thank god. Also salvaged was the 250GB Samsung EVO SSD "C" drive. It was cloned to a duplicate the 1st day of every month. (No, it hasn't been overclocked in 8+ years, and even then I had the shut down temps set @ 50c). New m/b, processor, video card, memory, and unfortunately, Win10 Pro x64. All do in Friday. :-(. This old (76) man is gonna have to learn all over again:-( ( 'cept this time it's air-cooled and VERY conservative :-) )

My problem is the several hundred bookmarks I had in Firefox (I'm a LONGTIME user. I DON'T want to loose them. I've got the salvaged "C" drive SSD in a mini-dock (D:/ in the laptop) and I'm looking at them on my laptop (also Win7 Pro x64 based) ALL the files appear to be there at the time of the failure. I've already copied a bunch of the files from it so I'm not shut off completely. When I try to use the Mozilla feature to transfer them, it appears it want's to re-install & rewrite Firefox on the D:/ drive. NOT good. Isn't there a single (even multiple) file(s) that can be copied to C:\ so I can disconnect the mini-dock and THEN "import" them?

THANK YOU !!!!
creator: my61cat

title: I can't play videos on youtube when I'm signed into my account
content:
Firefox 78.10.1 esr 64 bit Windows 10.0.19041.985

This question was originally asked here, https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/971100 , but has since been archived. YouTube videos load when not logged in, but will not load when logged into my YouTube account. They produce the following error:

  • An error occurred. Please try again later. (Playback ID: [random generated hash])

The advice offered in the cited Mozilla Support article assumes the problem is with Firefox, and had users delete their entire SQL-Lite cookie database, even though users reported that the error persisted after a clean install. Yes, it can sometimes be a cookie database issue, but this time, MAY 2021, it's a problem with YouTube's ad loader. This has happened before [1]. The work around until they fix it is to click on any suggested video on the same page. As soon as it starts to load, hit the browser's back button, and the error producing video will load.

[1] https://support.google.com/youtube/thread/10329866/consistently-getting-an-error-occurred-please-try-again-later-playback-id-on-all-videos?hl=en
creator: eckman
